__data__.text:
- 1922: WEAF, a laboratory for AT&T's manufacturing and supply outlet Western Electric, starts broadcasting and becomes an immediate success.
- 1923: RCA acquires WEAF from AT&T and transfers WJZ from Westinghouse to RCA.
- 1923: RCA attempts to transmit audio between cities via low-quality telegraph lines, but the effort fails due to interference.
- 1925: AT&T sells WEAF and WCAP to RCA, which creates the National Broadcasting Company (NBC) in late 1926.
- NBC is split into two networks: the "Red Network" (commercially sponsored entertainment and music programming) and the "Blue Network" (mostly non-sponsored broadcasts, especially news and cultural programs).
- 1927: NBC expands to the West Coast with the launch of the NBC Orange Network (Pacific Coast Network) and the NBC Gold Network (Pacific Gold Network).
- 1931: The Orange Network carries Red Network programming, and the Gold Network carries Blue Network programming.
- 1933: NBC moves its operations to 711 Fifth Avenue in Manhattan.
- 1930s: NBC develops a network for shortwave radio stations, called the NBC White Network.
- 1930: General Electric is charged with antitrust violations, resulting in the company's decision to divest itself of RCA.
- 1931: RCA signs leases to move its corporate headquarters into the new Rockefeller Center in 1933.
- 1933: RCA becomes the lead tenant at 30 Rockefeller Plaza, known as the "RCA Building" (later the GE Building, now the Comcast Building).

- NBC outgrew its Fifth Avenue facilities in 1933 and moved to the Rockefeller Center, becoming the lead tenant at the RCA Building (now the Comcast Building).
- NBC developed a network for shortwave radio stations, called the NBC White Network, in the 1930s.
- General Electric, an early shareholder in NBC's founding parent RCA, divested itself of RCA in 1930 due to antitrust violations.
- The NBC chimes, with the sequence G-E'-C', were first heard over Red Network affiliate WSB in Atlanta and were later adopted by NBC for use on the national network. The chimes became the first audio trademark to be accepted by the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office.
- In the late 1930s, Baltimore & Ohio Railroad reached an agreement with NBC to use the network's tones to summon passengers to dinner on its trains.
- The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) ordered RCA to divest itself of either NBC Red or NBC Blue in 1941 due to monopolistic effects of network broadcasting.
- The Blue Network was formally named NBC Blue Network, Inc. and NBC Red became NBC Red Network, Inc. for corporate purposes.
- The Blue Network was sold to the American Broadcasting System, owned by Life Savers magnate Edward J. Noble, for $8 million in 1943 after RCA lost its final appeal before the U.S. Supreme Court.

- The Blue Network was formally named NBC Blue Network, Inc. and NBC Red became NBC Red Network, Inc. for corporate purposes.
- Blue Network became known on-air as "Blue" or "Blue Network" and Blue Network Company, Inc. served as its official corporate name.
- NBC Red became known on-air as simply "NBC".
- Investment firm Dillon, Read & Co. placed a $7.5 million bid for NBC Blue, which was rejected.
- RCA sold Blue Network Company, Inc. to American Broadcasting System, owned by Edward J. Noble for $8 million.
- After the sale, Noble acquired the rights to the Blue Network name, leases on landlines, the New York studios, two-and-a-half radio stations, contracts with actors, and agreements with around 60 affiliates.
- Noble sold off his existing New York City radio station WMCA to comply with FCC radio station ownership limits.
- Noble acquired the branding rights to the "American Broadcasting Company" name from George B. Storer in 1944.
- The Blue Network became ABC officially on June 15, 1945.
- NBC became home to many popular performers and programs on the air, including Bing Crosby, Al Jolson, Jack Benny, Edgar Bergen, Bob Hope, Fred Allen, and Burns and Allen.
- NBC stations were often the most powerful, and some occupied unique clear-channel national frequencies.
- In the late 1940s, rival CBS gained ground by allowing radio stars to use their own production companies to produce programs.
- In 1948 and 1949, many NBC performers, including Jack Benny, Edgar Bergen and Charlie McCarthy, Burns and Allen and Frank Sinatra, jumped to CBS.
- NBC stars began migrating to television, including comedian Milton Berle.
- Conductor Arturo Toscanini conducted the NBC Symphony Orchestra in ten television concerts on NBC between 1948 and 1952.
- Aiming to keep classic radio alive as television matured, NBC launched The Big Show in November 1950.
- The Big Show was a 90-minute variety show that featured stage legend Tallulah

- The Big Show, hosted by Tallulah Bankhead and featuring prestigious entertainers, was NBC's last major radio programming push. Despite critical praise, it lasted only two years (1950-1952) due to increasing television viewership. NBC lost around $1 million on the project.
- Monitor, a creation of NBC President Sylvester "Pat" Weaver, was NBC's continuous all-weekend radio programming, featuring music, news, interviews, and features. It was successful for several years but declined in the mid-1960s as local stations were reluctant to break from established formats.
- Toscanini: The Man Behind the Legend, commemorating the great conductor's NBC broadcasts and recordings, ran for several years beginning in 1963.
- NBC News and Information Service (NIS) was launched in 1975, providing up to 55 minutes of news per hour around the clock to local stations. It ended operations in 1977 due to profitability concerns.
- The Source, launched in 1979, provided news and short features to FM rock stations.
- NBC Radio Network pioneered personal advice call-in national talk radio with TalkNet in the 1980s, featuring Bruce Williams, Bernard Meltzer, and Sally Jessy Raphael.
- GE reacquired RCA in 1985 and sold off NBC's radio holdings. Westwood One bought NBC Radio Network, The Source, NBC Talknet, and NBC Radio Entertainment for $50 million in 1987.
- NBC Radio News moved to Mutual's Arlington, Virginia, facility in 1989, with further consolidation in 1992 and 1994. Infinity purchased 25 percent of Westwood One, becoming its largest shareholder and assuming control.

- In the late 1980s, radio stations were sold off in multiple transactions, with Mutual's newsroom moving to Arlington, Virginia, in 1989.
- Further consolidation in 1992 led to joint production of Mutual and NBC newscasts in overnights and weekends.
- In 1994, Infinity purchased 25% of Westwood One, becoming its largest shareholder and assuming control.
- Infinity was acquired by Westinghouse Electric Corporation in 1996, with CBS Radio Network also falling under Westwood One management.
- The Mutual/NBC newsroom in Arlington closed in 1998, with CBS Radio News originating "Mutual" and "NBC" newscasts from New York.
- In 1999, "NBC"-branded newscasts were restricted to morning drive (ET) on weekdays.
- Westwood One partnered with NBC News to launch NBC News Radio in 2003, featuring one-minute newscasts on weekdays.
- Dial Global ended distribution of CNN Radio newscasts and made NBC News Radio a full-time operation in April 2012.
- Cumulus Media acquired Dial Global in 2013, which reverted to the Westwood One name and was merged into Cumulus Media Networks.
- NBC News Radio ended operations on December 15, 2014, and iHeartMedia produces "NBC News Radio"-branded newscasts via a licensing agreement.
- NBC was closely identified with David Sarnoff, who used it as a vehicle to sell consumer electronics.
- NBC and RCA introduced all-electronic television to the public at the 1939-40 New York World's Fair, with the first U.S. president to appear on television, President Franklin D. Roosevelt, on April 30, 1939.
- The first NBC Television "network" program was broadcast on January 12, 1940.

- In 1938, DuMont Laboratories offered the first home television sets in anticipation of NBC's announced April 1939 television launch.
- NBC broadcast the first network program on January 12, 1940, with Meet The Wife originating from W2XBS studios and rebroadcast by W2XB/W2XAF in Schenectady.
- Occasional special events were also broadcast in Philadelphia and Schenectady, with the most ambitious being the telecast of the Republican National Convention in 1940.
- Despite promotion by RCA, television sales in New York from 1939 to 1942 were disappointing due to high costs and lack of compelling programming.
- Few thousand television sets were sold, mainly to bars, hotels, and public places.
- The first commercial television broadcasts and paid advertisements began on July 1, 1941, on NBC's WNBT.
- Bulova, a watch manufacturer, aired the first official paid advertisement before a Brooklyn Dodgers baseball telecast.
- Non-paid television commercials existed on an experimental basis since 1930, with NBC's earliest seen during the first MLB game telecast in 1939.
- Telecasts were reduced during the early years of WWII, then expanded as NBC prepared for full-time service upon the war's end.
- A few programs were sent from New York City to affiliated stations in Philadelphia and Albany/Schenectady on a regular weekly schedule beginning in 1944.
- The Voice of Firestone Televues, a television offshoot of The Voice of Firestone radio show, was the first regular weekly transmission from New York City to Philadelphia and Schenectady, starting on April 10, 1944.

- NBC's commercial programming continued until the U.S. entered WWII, with telecasts curtailed and then expanded as NBC prepared for full-time service upon the war's end.
- The first regularly scheduled program on the NBC television network was The Voice of Firestone Televues, a television offshoot of The Voice of Firestone radio show, which began transmitting from New York City to Philadelphia and Schenectady on a regular, weekly basis starting on April 10, 1944.
- "The War As It Happens" was the first news cast regularly seen in multiple cities, beginning as a local program but fed to Schenectady and Philadelphia on the NBC Television Network in April 1944.
- On V-E Day, May 8, 1945, WNBT broadcast several hours of news coverage and remotes from around New York City, including a camera placed atop the marquee of the Hotel Astor panning the crowd below celebrating the end of the war in Europe.
- The NBC television network grew from its initial post-war line-up of four stations, with additional stations along the East Coast and in the Midwest connected by coaxial cable through the late 1940s.
- Television's first major star, Milton Berle, drew large audiences to NBC Television with Texaco Star Theatre beginning in June 1948.
- Under president Sylvester "Pat" Weaver, NBC launched Today and The Tonight Show, which would bookend the broadcast day for over 50 years, and which still lead their competitors.
- Weaver also launched the genre of periodic 90-minute network "spectaculars", network-produced motion pictures, and the live 90-minute Sunday afternoon series Wide Wide World.
- NBC commissioned Italian-American composer Gian Carlo Menotti to compose the first opera ever written for television, Amahl and the Night Visitors, which was a stunning success and repeated every year on NBC from 1951 to 1966.
- Rival CBS broadcast the first color television programs in the United States, but their system was incompatible with the millions of black and white sets in use at the time.
- RCA convinced the FCC to approve its color system in December 1953,

- CBS abandoned its color broadcast system in 1953, allowing RCA's compatible color system to be adopted as the U.S. standard.
- NBC was ready with color programming within days of the FCC's decision and began broadcasting shows in color in 1954.
- NBC's first program to air all episodes in color was "The Marriage" in 1954.
- NBC broadcast a live production of "Peter Pan" in color in 1955, which was a huge success and led to restagings in 1956 and 1960.
- NBC started a subsidiary, California National Productions (CNP), in 1956 for merchandising, syndication and NBC opera company operations.
- WNBQ, NBC's owned-and-operated station in Chicago, became the first television station in the country to broadcast its programming in color in 1956.
- "The Bell Telephone Hour" premiered on NBC in color in 1959 and aired for nine more years.
- NBC acquired the rights to Walt Disney's anthology series in 1961 and began airing it in color.
- NBC's telecast of the Rose Bowl became the first college football game to be telecast in color in 1962.
- NBC began broadcasting 95% of its prime time schedule in color in 1963 and began billing itself as "The Full Color Network" in 1965.
- Days of Our Lives became the first soap opera to premiere in color when it debuted in November 1965.
- NBC contracted with Universal Studios in 1964 to produce the first feature-length film produced for television, "See How They Run."
- NBC reached a deal with MGM in 1967 to acquire the broadcast rights to the classic 1939 film "The Wizard of Oz."

- In 1967, NBC acquired the rights to broadcast The Wizard of Oz from MGM, after CBS refused to meet the increased fee to renew its television rights.
- The Wizard of Oz was significant as it was one of the few programs that CBS had telecast in color, but by 1967, color broadcasts had become standard on television.
- NBC aired The Wizard of Oz each year from 1968 to 1976, when CBS re-acquired the rights to show the film.
- The late 1960s saw major changes in the programming practices of the major television networks, as they aimed to attract younger viewers and modernize programming.
- NBC, CBS, and ABC defined adults between the ages of 18 and 49 as their main target audience, with subdivisions into other age demos.
- The 1970s started strongly for NBC, but the network entered a slump in the middle of the decade despite successful new shows and continued success from veterans.
- In 1974, NBC tried to attract younger viewers with costly movies, miniseries, and specials, but this failed and alienated older viewers.
- In 1975, none of the new prime-time shows that NBC introduced earned a second season renewal, except for NBC's Saturday Night (later renamed Saturday Night Live).
- In 1978, Fred Silverman was lured away from top-rated ABC to turn NBC's fortunes around, but he was unable to pull out a hit except for a few shows.
- Failures accumulated rapidly under Silverman's watch, such as Hello, Larry, Supertrain, Pink Lady and Jeff, season six of Saturday Night Live, and The Waverly Wonders.

* Fred Silverman, while at NBC, was unable to produce many hits, with shows like CHiPs, Barbara Mandrell and the Mandrell Sisters, Diff'rent Strokes, Real People, and Shōgun being notable exceptions.
* Silverman's tenure at NBC was marked by several failures, including Hello, Larry, Supertrain, Pink Lady and Jeff, The Krofft Superstar Hour, season six of Saturday Night Live, and The Waverly Wonders.
* Many of these shows were beaten in the ratings by shows that Silverman had greenlit during his previous tenures at CBS and ABC.
* During this time, several longtime NBC affiliates defected to other networks, including ABC and CBS.
* Most of the defecting stations were VHF stations, with some exceptions being UHF stations such as WAAY-TV, WATR-TV, KLAA-TV, and KERO.
* In markets such as San Diego, Fort Smith, Charlotte, Knoxville, and Jacksonville, NBC had little choice but to affiliate with a UHF station.
* Some smaller television markets, like Yuma, Arizona, waited many years to get another local NBC affiliate.
* Some of the stations that defected from NBC have since rejoined the network, while others have switched to different networks.
* In Rapid City, the KOTA calls now resist on a station owned by Gray Television.
* The passage ends with a mention of President Jimmy Carter pulling the U.S. out of something, but no context is provided.

- NBC's affiliation upgraded in Wheeling by partnering with WTOV-TV in Steubenville, OH, overtaking former affiliate WTRF-TV.
- Smaller markets like Yuma, AZ, took years to get another local NBC affiliate.
- Baltimore, Columbia, Dayton, Jacksonville, Savannah, and Temple rejoined NBC, while El Dorado, Green Bay, and Bakersfield switched to other networks.
- KOTA calls now resist on a station owned by Gray Television in Rapid City.
- After President Jimmy Carter pulled the U.S. team out of the 1980 Summer Olympics, NBC canceled its 150 hours of coverage, placing the network's future in doubt.
- Fred Silverman faced criticism from within NBC, leading to the creation of a parody song "Loud as a Peacock" and a sketch on SNL titled "A Limo For A Lame-O".
- Grant Tinker and Brandon Tartikoff took over as president and entertainment division president, respectively, in the summer of 1981.
- Tartikoff showed patience with promising programs, including Hill Street Blues, St. Elsewhere, and Cheers.
- NBC's biggest hit during this period was The A-Team, which helped the network through the disastrous 1983-84 season.
- Tom Snyder's The Tomorrow Show was canceled, and David Letterman took over the 12:35 a.m. time slot with Late Night with David Letterman.
- The Cosby Show's success in 1984 led to a renewed interest in sitcoms, and Family Ties and Cheers saw increased viewership.

- In 1982, NBC gave the 12:35 a.m. time slot to David Letterman, who hosted Late Night with David Letterman until 1993.
- The Cosby Show's success in 1984 led to a renewed interest in sitcoms and increased viewership for Family Ties and Cheers.
- NBC rose to second place in the ratings in 1984-85 and first place in 1985-86 with shows like The Golden Girls, Miami Vice, and ALF.
- Bob Wright was appointed as chairman of NBC in 1986.
- NBC became the first American television network to broadcast programs in stereo in 1985.
- NBC repaired old affiliations with stations like Savannah, Temple, Columbia, Jacksonville, and WOWT in the mid-1980s.
- In 1987, NBC conceived a syndication package for its owned-and-operated stations called "Prime Time Begins at 7:30".
- The syndication package consisted of five sitcoms, including Marblehead Manor, She's the Sheriff, You Can't Take It with You, Out of This World, and We Got It Made.
- The package was aimed at attracting viewers to NBC stations in the half-hour preceding prime time.
- The shows were regularly outrated by syndicated game shows like Wheel of Fortune, Jeopardy!, and Hollywood Squares.
- Marblehead Manor, We Got It Made, and You Can't Take It With You were cancelled after the 1987-88 season, while She's the Sheriff lasted one more season in weekend syndication.

- In 1987, NBC planned to increase in-house productions, including half-hour dramedies, and introduced an experimental sitcom lineup for Thanksgiving weekend.
 
- The same year, NBC's new soap opera, Generations, caused low ratings for the network's daytime lineup.

- NBC confirmed the integration of NBC Enterprises division with NBC-TV and Corporate Communications.

- NBC aired the first of eight consecutive Summer Olympic Games broadcasts with the 1988 Games in Seoul, South Korea.

- In the 1988-89 season, NBC had 17 series in Nielsen's year-end Top 30 and ranked first in weekly ratings for over 12 months.

- 1989 was NBC's final year of covering Major League Baseball, but the network continued its success with new hits like The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air, Blossom, and Law & Order.

- Brandon Tartikoff, NBC's President of Entertainment from 1981 to 1991, increased NBC's shows in the Nielsen Top 10 from zero to five.

- Warren Littlefield succeeded Tartikoff, facing challenges as Tartikoff-era hits ended. Criticism arose when David Letterman left for CBS, and Jay Leno took over The Tonight Show.

- New hits like Mad About You, Wings, Sisters, Frasier, Friends, ER, and Will & Grace helped NBC recover.

- Seinfeld, acquired by Tartikoff, struggled at first but became a top-rated show after moving to Thursdays following Cheers. It ended as the U.S. television program with the highest Nielsen ratings in its final season.

- Friends became NBC's biggest show after Seinfeld, dominating the ratings and never leaving the top five watched shows from seasons two through ten.

- Frasier, a Cheers spinoff, was a critical and commercial success, usually in the Nielsen Top 20, and won numerous Emmy Awards.

- Friends was a highly successful sitcom that aired on NBC from 1994 to 2004, and was the network's biggest show after Seinfeld ended.
- It was part of NBC's "Must See TV" lineup on Thursday nights, along with shows like Seinfeld, Will & Grace, and ER.
- Friends was the number one show in the Nielsen ratings during the 2001-2002 season.
- Frasier, a spin-off of Cheers, was also a successful show that aired on NBC from 1993 to 2004.
- In the mid-1990s, NBC had rights to the NFL, Major League Baseball, the NBA, the Olympics, and Notre Dame football.
- In 1998, NBC lost the rights to the AFC to CBS, which was a major blow to the network's sports division.
- Garth Ancier replaced Scott Sassa as president of NBC Entertainment in 1999, and Jeff Zucker succeeded Ancier in 2000.
- In the early 2000s, CBS overtook NBC in the ratings and Survivor was moved to Thursday nights, posing a threat to NBC's longstanding dominance on the night.
- NBC began airing select dramas in letterbox in the early 2000s in an attempt to attract new viewers.

- In 2001, CBS overtook NBC for the ratings lead, but NBC remained strong with shows like "Friends," "Will & Grace," "ER," and "Just Shoot Me!" on Thursday nights.
- Between 2001-2002 and 2004-2005, NBC became the first major network to air select dramas in letterbox over its analog broadcast feed, but only saw a slight boost in ratings.
- NBC lost the broadcast rights to Major League Baseball in 2000 and the NBA in 2002, reducing its major sports offerings to the Olympics, PGA Tour golf events, and a struggling Notre Dame football program.
- In 2001, NBC acquired Spanish-language network Telemundo for $2.7 billion.
- In 2003, General Electric bought 80% of Vivendi Universal Entertainment, integrating NBC with Vivendi Universal's properties under the NBC Universal brand.
- In 2004, Jeff Zucker became president of NBC Universal Television Group and Kevin Reilly became the new president of NBC Entertainment.
- In 2004, NBC faced a "three on a match" scenario with the end of "Friends" and "Frasier," and the sudden death of "Law & Order's" Jerry Orbach.
- The network's ratings fell to fourth place in 2005-2006, with only "My Name Is Earl" surviving for a second season.
- NBC's ratings decline was due to increased competition from cable television, home video, video games, and the Internet.
- The 2006-2007 season was mixed for NBC, with "Deal or No Deal" remaining strong and "Heroes" becoming a surprise hit, while "Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip" was canceled.
- "The Office" and "30 Rock" were critically acclaimed sitcoms that pulled in modest successes for NBC.

- NBC's ratings fell to fourth place in the 2006-07 season, with increased competition from cable TV, home video, video games, and the Internet.
- The network had mixed results that season, with strong ratings for Deal or No Deal and the success of Heroes on Monday nights.
- Critically acclaimed sitcoms The Office and 30 Rock also performed well, winning the Emmy Award for Outstanding Comedy Series for four consecutive years.
- NBC regained the rights to NFL's Sunday Night Football, but remained in fourth place.
- America's Got Talent, a reality talent competition series, earned high ratings in the summer but was not used to boost the network's fall lineup.
- Kevin Reilly was replaced by Ben Silverman as president of NBC Entertainment, and Jeff Zucker became CEO of NBC.
- The network failed to generate new primetime hits in the 2008-09 season, with Heroes and Deal or No Deal collapsing in the ratings.
- Comcast announced a $15.6 billion deal to purchase a 51% controlling stake in NBC Universal from General Electric in 2009.
- NBC's broadcast of the 2010 Winter Olympics generated a ratings increase of 21% over the 2006 games, but the network lost $250 million in advertising revenue.
- The 2009-10 season ended with only two scripted shows and three unscripted shows being renewed for second seasons.
- After Conan O'Brien succeeded Jay Leno as host of The Tonight Show, Leno was given a new prime time talk show at 10:00 p.m.

- 2009-2010 season:
  - Only two scripted shows (Community and Parenthood) and three unscripted shows (The Marriage Ref, Who Do You Think You Are? and Minute to Win It) renewed for second seasons
  - Heroes and Law & Order cancelled
  - Jay Leno given prime time talk show at 10:00 p.m. Eastern and Pacific
  - NBC became first major U.S. broadcast network to air same program in week daily prime time strip
  - Decision criticized by industry executives
  - Leno's show moved to 11:35 p.m. slot in January 2010
  - Removal of The Jay Leno Show had little impact on network's ratings
  - By 2012, shows in 10:00 p.m. time slot drew lower numbers than The Jay Leno Show
  - Comcast announced acquisition of majority interest in NBC Universal from General Electric
  - Jeff Zucker stepped down as NBC Universal's CEO
  - Steve Burke named CEO of NBCUniversal and Robert Greenblatt replaced Jeff Gaspin as chairman of NBC Entertainment

- 2010-2011 season:
  - NBC found a breakout hit in reality singing competition series The Voice
  - Every single new fall program cancelled by season's end
  - Harry's Law only freshman scripted series renewed for 2011-2012 season
  - NBC nearly completed full conversion to an all-HD schedule

- 2011-2012 season:
  - Network's broadcast of Super Bowl XLVI was most-watched program in U.S. television history at the time
  - Network's Monday night midseason lineup of The Voice and musical-drama Smash successful
  - Network lifted itself into third place in the 18-49 demographic
  - Four shows survived for a second season, but three were cancelled in the following year
  - Network remained a distant fourth place in total viewership
  - NBC greatly expanded its sitcom roster, with eight comedy series airing on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday nights.

* Super Bowl XLVI broadcast was the most-watched program in U.S. television history at the time.
* NBC's Monday night midseason lineup of The Voice and Smash was successful.
* NBC finished 3rd in the 18-49 demographic in the 2011-12 season, breaking an 8-year streak in 4th place.
* Four shows survived for a second season, but three were cancelled in the following year.
* NBC expanded its sitcom roster in the fall of 2012, with eight comedy series airing on Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday nights.
* NBC bounced back to first place network in adults 18-49 that fall, but fell to fifth place in February 2013 sweeps period.
* NBC finished the 2012-13 season in third place overall.
* NBC Sports migrated its business and production operations to new facilities in Stamford, Connecticut in 2013.
* The 2013-14 season was successful for NBC, finishing as the No. 1 network in the 18-49 demographic for the first time since 2003-04.
* NBC launched eight new series in the 2014-15 season, with only one being renewed for a second season.
* NBC finished #1 in the 18-49 demographic and in second place overall in the 2014-15 season.
* The 2015-16 season was successful for NBC, with the successful launch of Blindspot and Chicago Med.
* Thursday nights continued to be a struggle for NBC in the 2015-16 season.
* NBC found success with police procedural Shades of Blue in the 2015-16 season.
* NBC launched the new workplace sitcom Superstore in the 2015-16 season, which was renewed for a second season.
* The 2016-17 season brought more success for NBC with the premiere of comedy-drama This Is Us.
* The Blacklist continued to bring in modest ratings, but it brought the failed launch of its spinoff The Blacklist: Redemption.
* NBC continued to grow the Chicago

- NBC's comedy series "Superstore" premiered in November 2015 and was renewed for a second season in February 2016.
- Comedy-drama "This Is Us" premiered in 2016, received positive reviews, and was renewed for two additional seasons in January 2017.
- "The Blacklist" continued to bring modest ratings, but its spinoff "The Blacklist: Redemption" failed.
- NBC expanded the "Chicago" franchise with the addition of "Chicago Justice" in 2016-17.
- "The Good Place," a fantasy sitcom, premiered in 2016-17 and was renewed for a second season in January 2017.
- "The Wall" debuted in 2016-17 with modest ratings and aired during the summer before the 2017-18 season.
- In 2017-18, "Ellen's Game of Games" and the return of "Will & Grace" contributed to NBC's success.
- "The Titan Games," "Manifest," "Songland," and "New Amsterdam" premiered in 2018-19 and were renewed for additional seasons.
- "The Village" and "The Enemy Within" were not renewed beyond their first seasons in 2018-19.
- NBC was the top-rated network in the 2010s, but its dominance faded during the 2019-20 season due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
- The network moved to #2 in the Nielsen ratings in 2021 and reclaimed its status as the top-rated network in 2022.
